item.title: Don‚Äôt Download PS Plus‚Äôs Latest Batch Of Games Until You‚Äôve Read This
item.content:encoded:
If you‚Äôre rushing to grab the latest round of free-ish games included in October‚Äôs PS Plus Extra or Premium bundle, you might want to slow your horses slightly and double-check that you aren‚Äôt about to accidentally lose your ownership of one of the games forever. Due to an ongoing bug with the PlayStation‚Äôs current subscription service, if you previously picked up PS Plus Essential‚Äôs giveaway of Yakuza: Like a Dragon in 2022, downloading it again today will erase your license to own it completely!

This issue is pointed out by PlayStation Lifestyle‚Äòs Zarmena Khan, who has been trying to raise awareness of this hefty problem ever since Sony relaunched its PS Plus service three years ago. It boils down like this: Back in the day, when you downloaded the monthly freebies from PS Plus Essential, they were yours to keep for so long as you maintained your subscription. It was a great deal, and made logging in at the start of a month‚Äîwell‚Äîessential. However, in 2022 this changed, with PS Plus shifting to be more like Microsoft‚Äôs Game Pass, such that the games are only accessible to play so long as they remain a part of the PS Plus catalog. Once they‚Äôre gone from there, you can no longer play them without paying for the full version. The problem is, if you picked up a game via the Essential service and then re-download it via the modern PS Plus, your original license is permanently overwritten and you‚Äôll lose access to a game you previously owned once its time on the sub comes to an end. And that‚Äôs pretty bad!

This month makes this issue particularly relevant, with Yakuza: Like a Dragon, which was originally given away as part of PS Plus Essential in August 2022, now available in the catalog. Reddit user kabirsingh84 first raised the concern yesterday, reminding people that the PS Plus Extra version that arrives today will delete your license.

So before you grab it‚Äîand indeed any other game added to the PS Plus subscription‚Äîmake sure to check your library to see if you picked it up any time before 2022. It‚Äôs so easy to have grabbed all three games in any given month, forgot you ever did, and then too easily lose your ongoing right to play it.

Of course, this all shines a bright light on the degree to which we increasingly don‚Äôt own the majority of the games we play, or even buy, as consumer rights are eroded by deeply dubious digital licenses.

item.title: Samsung Quietly Clears Out Galaxy S25 Edge 512GB Before the Black Friday Rush While Apple Sticks to Full Price
item.content:encoded:
As the name implies, the Samsung Galaxy S25 Edge is slim. It measures in at under a quarter inch thick. Beyond that, you‚Äôre getting the quintessential Samsung Galaxy experience with this phone. The Samsung Galaxy S25 family of phones come in a few different storage capacity options plus a whole slew of colors, but right now the Edge model with 512GB is deeply on sale. You‚Äôll save 40% on the specifically the titanium silver and titanium jet black options. They normally go for $1,220, but the discount brings them down by $490. That makes it so you only have to pay $730 for a limited time.

Just because this model phone is extra thin, doesn‚Äôt mean it‚Äôs sacrificing any toughness. Each is made with a durable titanium build along with a Corning Gorilla Glass Ceramic 2 face.

See at Amazon

Superior Photography

Despite how thin the phone is, the S25 Edge is still able to pack in Samsung‚Äôs powerful 200MP camera. You can capture every stunning detail with the highest resolution camera on any Galaxy phone. It also includes and ultra wide auto-focus 12MP camera plus the 12MP selfie camera on the front.

One of the more practical uses of Galaxy AI integration in the S25 Edge is when it comes to the camera. The Samsung smartphone employs a feature called Best Face. You ever set up to take a group photo, snap a bunch in a row, then look back through them only to see there‚Äôs something wrong with each of them? Maybe Jolie blinked in the first, then Daniel got distracted and turned his head in the next. None of them are post-worthy. Well, Best Face can intelligently take everyone‚Äôs best look across all the photos and stitch them together into one perfect shot. It only takes a few seconds and can provide results for group photos of up to five people.

Selfies are also elevated when taken on the Galaxy S25 Edge. Galaxy AI can recognize your environment‚Äôs lighting and capture accurate skin tone, balancing the levels on the fly without any extra editing.

Finding photos through your camera roll has also been made easier. If you‚Äôre trying to find a specific pic you took, you can just describe it in your search to have Galaxy AI dig through your photos to bring you to it. Like maybe you dress your dog up as a Dracula for Halloween but you don‚Äôt remember what year that was. Just type in ‚Äúvampire dog‚Äù and it should come up.

item.title: Don‚Äôt Be A Coward, Put Your Pok√©mon Starter In A Box
item.content:encoded:
The Pok√©mon franchise is an excellent propaganda machine. Thanks to the anime focusing so heavily on the powerful bond between Ash and his starter Pok√©mon, Pikachu, everyone feels like they have to love their first partner in each game. These cute little guys are typically given to you by a professor, and they serve as an early foundation for the rest of the team you‚Äôll build out over the course of the game. But sometimes, you‚Äôll boot one of these games up and realize you don‚Äôt like any of your options. Then you‚Äôre stuck with this hangnail of a Pok√©mon you don‚Äôt really care about. Friends, what if I told you that there‚Äôs another option? One that most trainers, chained down by sentimentality, never even consider? Put that little shit in the box and catch your actual fave.

Every time a new Pok√©mon game comes out, fans decide which of the three starter monsters they‚Äôll be taking out on their adventure. These fire, water, and grass-type Pok√©mon are meant to give new players a sense of the series‚Äô rock-paper-scissors-style types and weaknesses, and usually end up being faces of the franchise for a few years until the next game comes out. The Legends games, however, have handled this a bit differently. Instead of three new critters to start your journey with, these experimental spin-off RPGs bring back old starters from previous games, but with a new twist. Arceus gives Rowlet, Cyndaquil, and Oshawatt‚Äôs final stages regional variants, and Z-A gives Chikorita, Tepig, and Totodile Mega Evolutions. 

Z-A, however, has gotten a bit of flak for its starter choice which includes Chikorita and Tepig, arguably two of the least popular starters in Pok√©mon history even though they are both my special babies who have never done anything wrong. So if you fire up a new Pok√©mon game only to find yourself greeted with three Pok√©mon you‚Äôre not particularly thrilled about, are you just forced to use them for several dozen hours? No, my friend. That‚Äôs just what Big Pok√©mon Company wants you to think.

While I‚Äôve never boxed a starter during my initial playthrough, I‚Äôm no stranger to treating my game-sanctioned first partner like any other Pok√©mon on my team. That‚Äôs because the second I boot up one of these games, I‚Äôm looking for my real starter: a Pichu or PIkachu. My favorite Pok√©mon is Raichu, and because it‚Äôs the evolved form of the series‚Äô mascot, my basic ass has the wonderful privilege of knowing my favorite boy is going to be in most games (we don‚Äôt talk about Black and White). So every time I pick a starter in these games, I know they‚Äôre going to end up playing second fiddle to my electric rat. I learned at an early age that I don‚Äôt have to believe the lie that my starter has to be my best friend, because they‚Äôre often just a placeholder for the little yellow guy in my mind. That was true in Z-A. I picked Chikorita, and when he evolved into Meganium, he was a surprise MVP of my playthrough thanks to the new grass/fairy-type Mega Evolution. But even though my time in Lumiose City began with this Pok√©mon, he didn‚Äôt have to be in my party any longer than it took me to catch another critter. In fact, most games barely acknowledge the starter after you initially get one. 

In Pok√©mon Legends: Z-A, we have one of the more underwhelming starter line-ups ever, at least for people who hate good and cute babies like Chikorita and Tepig, with Totodile being far and away the most popular of the trio. What if you don‚Äôt need a water-type Pok√©mon in your party because your favorite is Gyarados? Did Totodile‚Äôs ugly Mega Evolution after it becomes Feraligatr put you off the blue dude altogether? The secret no one at Game Freak wants you to know is that you can put that little guy in a box and make a party that has no starters in it at all. Hell, take it a step further and release that red-headed stepchild back into the wild. Taunie and Urbain don‚Äôt have to know you sent their Pok√©mon down the street with a bindle. Break free of the chains of decades of Ash and Pikachu brainwashing and write your own story.

item.title: Upcoming Steam Game Lets You Be A Horrible Date
item.content:encoded:
Dating isn‚Äôt easy. Especially if you happen to be a poor female soul cursed with wanting to date men (it‚Äôs me, I am poor female soul). When they don‚Äôt seem checked out, they‚Äôre busy telling you the elaborate details of how their marriage collapsed over intimacy issues. Or confiding in you about their secret plans to make everyone in their polycule very unhappy. Maybe they won‚Äôt stop talking about video games (which can go either way, really). Or, as upcoming indie narrative game DateBoy simulates, maybe the guy you‚Äôre dating won‚Äôt stop playing video games. Ugh, my eyes are up here, buddy.

Developed by brothers Anton and Henri P√§tsi, DateBoy casts you in the role of a boy on a date at an Italian restaurant who is Checked Out‚Ñ¢, too busy playing video games under the table while his off-screen date struggles to carry on a conversation. It‚Äôs a free narrative game out on Steam and Itch.io next month and it looks delightfully amusing. Check out the trailer here:

Essentially you play as a dude on a date, trying to play a platformer that bears a passing resemblance to Gimmick! on a device that‚Äôs probably legally distinct from a certain beloved late ‚Äò90s handheld console. While hopping around in the platformer, you‚Äôll have to try and keep up with the usual, tired dating conversational topics such as ‚ÄúHow was your day?‚Äù with opportunities to deliver those one-word answers that us girls love hearing on a night out.

Oh well. At least there‚Äôs pizza.

The game promises to be no longer than half an hour. The Steam listing makes for an amusing read, too. So if you‚Äôre looking for what seems to be a cute narrative joint, maybe mark this one on your calendar and try not to stand it up.

item.title: LEGO Friends Advent Calendar Is the Only One Left, Now Selling 42% Off on Amazon
item.content:encoded:
LEGO released its 2025 Advent calendars just a few weeks ago, and they‚Äôre already vanishing from Amazon‚Äôs shelves at an alarming rate. The Lego City calendar is completely sold out, Minecraft has disappeared and most other themes have either limited stock or inflated prices. Surprisingly, the Lego Friends Advent Calendar remains available and has dropped to an all-time low of $20, down from its original $34 price. For parents trying to stretch holiday budgets while keeping the magic alive through December, this is one of those deals that won‚Äôt last long once word gets out.

See at Amazon

Advent calendars solve a specific parenting challenge every December: Kids need something to channel their excitement during those long weeks leading up to Christmas, and a daily surprise keeps them engaged without the sugar overload of chocolate-filled alternatives. This set delivers 237 pieces spread across 24 doors, giving children aged six and up a new building project each morning.

What‚Äôs Different This Year About The Calendar?

LEGO recently rebranded the Friends theme with greater emphasis on varied storytelling and everyday situations that children are more likely to connect with. This 2025 calendar shows that transition with a holiday sleepover theme that seems more down to earth than releases from earlier years. The package contains five mini-dolls: Aliya, Autumn, Liann, Nova, and Leo who come with sleeping mats that complete a whole indoor campout setup. The choice of characters reflects varied personality types and interests so that children may enter the narrative on several different levels.

The animal companions add another layer of play value: Two dogs, a guinea pig, a gecko, and a cat come with their own accessories like food stations, water dispensers, scratching posts and pet beds. Each animal‚Äôs accessories are scaled to match the mini-doll world so kids can actually integrate them into ongoing play scenarios beyond December.

The day-by-day builds range from tiny accessories in early December to larger interactive pieces as we build up to Christmas. Early dates may open with wrapped gift boxes or a table lamp, while later dates open up the fireplace with flame elements, a working sled with space for a minidoll, and a life-sized LEGO reindeer figure. The karaoke machine features a microphone piece that is compatible with a minidoll‚Äôs hand, and the hot chocolate stand includes mugs proportionate to the figures.

The scene-building potential extends well past December 25th. The sofa seats two minidolls comfortably, the Christmas tree comes with decorative elements that can be rearranged, and the hobbyhorse has a spring mechanism built into its base. These aren‚Äôt single-use holiday decorations. They become permanent additions to any existing LEGO Friends collection, compatible with playsets like the Heartlake City buildings and vehicles sold separately.

At $20, this calendar is cheaper than several single LEGO Friends expansion packs while offering more variety. The retail price of $34 already offered good value compared to purchasing single blind bags or accessory packs over the course of the year.

item.title: Yoko Taro Hides Clues When Signing Merchandise To Fight Scammers
item.content:encoded:
Selling autographed merchandise has become so lucrative that celebrities and athletes are told not to sign anything with blue ink because it‚Äôs believed that this makes their John Hancock easier to scan and forge. It‚Äôs true that if you don‚Äôt actually see someone sign something in front of you, it‚Äôs pretty difficult to verify if a signature is legitimate, so it‚Äôs good to be cautious when buying signed merchandise from a third party. Luckily some public figures, like Nier director Yoko Taro, are willing to call out phonies peddling fake autographs for profit.

A Nier fan on X sent Taro a screenshot of a now-deleted auction of an autographed Nier soundtrack CD that the director had seemingly signed. At a glance, you wouldn‚Äôt know that it was forged. It even has a little sketch of Emil, a character from the Nier series whose mask Taro wears during public appearances and that he often includes in his signatures. However, Taro himself replied that ‚Äúnearly half‚Äù of the items for sale that are ostensibly bearing his signature are forged, including the one the fan had originally sent. After Taro put it on blast, the original auction listing was taken down.

This autograph is a fake. I include small unknown features in my real autographs to prevent reselling, so I can tell when one isn‚Äôt genuine. I've confirmed that nearly half of the autographs being resold are actually fake, so please don't buy them.

Taro says he includes ‚Äúsmall, unknown features‚Äù in his signature to identify forgeries. A fan posted an image of Taro‚Äôs real signature as seen at a Square Enix event, and the differences are subtle but noticeable upon comparison. The R is longer, and the Y is kind of squiggly.

It‚Äôs also possible that forgeries get better now that those looking to make a quick buck know what to look for. So be careful out there, y‚Äôall. 

Normally, this is where I‚Äôd talk about what Taro is working on right now, but we don‚Äôt really know, actually. I just finished a replay of Nier: Automata, and as much as I know people want more of those games, I‚Äôm pretty content with where it all ended.
